title: Intalling SPSS
text:
1. Download SPSS
Open the page and expand the tab ‚ÄúDownload, Installation & License Activation‚Äù
(the yellow-highlighted section on the site).

Next, click Download Section for SPSS Statistics.

When a login window appears, sign in with your Medicampus ID
‚Äî just the username, without ‚Äú@uni-muenster.de‚Äù.

title: Intalling SPSS
section: 2. Choose Your Version and Operating System
text:
2. Choose Your Version and Operating System
You can download the most recent version available:

Then select your operating system (Windows, macOS):

Note: Options are available for Linux in the ‚ÄúArch‚Äù folder.

title: Intalling SPSS
text:
3. Activate SPSS
SPSS must be activated using the Network License option.
Go to the official activation page spss lizenzaktivierung
There, follow the steps under ‚ÄúActivating the Network License.‚Äù

title: Intalling SPSS
text:
4. Important Connection Requirement
To use SPSS, you must be connected to one of the following:

ms-uni WiFi, or

the university VPN

This connection is required whenever SPSS checks the license.

title: Practical 3
text:
Practical 3
Introduction: In this lesson, we will focus on confidence intervals, normal distribution, and transforming variables.

Exercise 1: Estimating with Confidence Intervals
Calculate the 95% confidence intervals for the mean values of the variables height and mortstat.
üí° SPSS:

Step 1:  Analyze ‚Üí Descriptive Statistics ‚Üí Explore

Step 2:  Assign height and mortstat as dependent variables.
Step 3:  Under ‚ÄúDisplay‚Äù, select ‚ÄúStatistics‚Äù.
Step 4:  In the ‚ÄúStatistics‚Äù menu, set the desired confidence interval limits.
Step 5:  Under ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù, choose ‚ÄúExclude cases pairwise‚Äù.



Show Results




Variable
Mean (95% Confidence Intervals)




height
167.05 (166.89 - 167.21)


mortstat
0.26 (0.25 - 0.27)




Comprehension question about Confidence Intervals:
Which statement do you agree with:

For a 95% confidence interval, the true population value lies within the limits of the interval with a probability of 95%.
A 95% confidence interval means that if multiple samples are drawn, 95% of the resulting intervals will contain the true population value. Whether the confidence interval contains the true value in an individual case cannot be determined.



Show Results

‚úì b) A 95% confidence interval means that if multiple samples are drawn, 95% of the resulting intervals will contain the true population value. Whether the confidence interval contains the true value in an individual case cannot be determined.



Exercise 2: Testing for normality
In the lecture, you learned about different ways to test for normality. In brief, these are:

Assessment of skewness and kurtosis (kurtosis should be 3 ‚Äì describes the steepness/peakedness of the distribution)
Statistical tests for normality
Graphical tests for normality

Knowledge about the distribution of variables can, among other things, help in selecting the appropriate test.
Check the variables height, bmi, and cal_mean for normality.
üí° SPSS:

Step 1:  Analyze ‚Üí Descriptive Statistics ‚Üí Explore

Step 2:  Under ‚ÄúDisplay‚Äù, select ‚ÄúBoth‚Äù.
Step 3:  In the ‚ÄúStatistics‚Äù menu, set the desired confidence interval limits.
Step 4:  Under ‚ÄúPlots‚Äù, choose ‚ÄúNormality plots with tests‚Äù and ‚ÄúHistogram‚Äù.
Step 5:  Assign height, bmi, and cal_mean as dependent variables.
For height, bmi, and cal_mean, test for normal distribution graphically by examining their histograms and Q-Q plots.
Determine which of the variables can be assumed to follow a normal distribution.



Assessment of skewness and kurtosis





Statistical tests for normality





Graphical tests for normality


Histograms



Q-Q plots





Show Results




Variable
Normal distribution




height
Yes


cal_mean
No


bmi
No






Exercise 3: Transforming Variables
Perform a logarithmic transformation of the variable cal_mean.
üí° SPSS

Step 1:  TRANSFORM ‚Üí COMPUTE VARIABLE

Step 2:  Assign a name to the target variable
Step 3:  ‚òë Select the Function Group ‚ÄúArithmetic‚Äù and double-click on Ln
Step 4:  Double-click the variable to be transformed

Take a look at the histogram with the normal distribution curve for the newly created variable:
üí° SPSS:

  Analyze
  ‚Üí
  Descriptive Statistics
    ‚Üí
  Frequencies

Under ‚ÄúCharts‚Äù, select ‚òë ‚ÄúHistogram‚Äù and ‚ÄúNormal distribution curve‚Äù


Show Results

title: Practical 5: Linear Regression
text:
Also known as: response, predicted, dependent variable

Type: Continuous
1 variable






Also known as: covariate, independent, explanatory, predictor variable

Type: Continuous or Categorical
One (Univariate) or Multiple (Multivariate)






In this practical, we use univariate linear regression to study the association between:

Covariate: Smoking (smk)

Levels: 1=Never, 2=Former, 3=Current
Reference: Never smokers

Outcome: Attachment loss (cal_mean)

Unit: mm









Build a univariable linear regression model to study the association between smoking (smk; 1=Never, 2=Former, 3=Current, set the never smokers as a reference group) and attachment loss (cal_mean; in mm).
Since the smoking variable has three levels, the first step is to create dummy variables.
1. Create a dummy variable for ‚ÄúFormer‚Äù smokers:
üí° SPSS:

Transform ‚Üí Recode into Different Variables

Step 2:  Select smk >> write Former under Name & Label >> press Change.
Step 3:  Click ‚ÄúOld and New Values‚Äù.
Step 4:  Configure values:

Under Old Value: enter 2 >> Under New Value: enter 1 >> Press Add.
Under Old Value: enter 1 >> Under New Value: enter 0 >> Press Add.
Under Old Value: enter 3 >> Under New Value: enter 0 >> Press Add.
Under Old Value: select System- or user-missing >> Under New Value: select System-missing >> Press Add.
Select All other values >> select Copy old value(s) >> Press Add. (This handles missing values)

Note: Ensure Measure is Nominal in Variable View, Decimals is set to 0, and Change Values to 0 = ‚ÄúCurrent/none‚Äù and 1 = ‚ÄúFormer‚Äù.






Your browser does not support the video tag. 

2. Repeat the same procedure to create a dummy variable for ‚ÄúCurrent‚Äù smokers. (Recode smk: 3 -> 1, 1 -> 0, 2 -> 0).
3. Fit the model
üí° SPSS:

Analyze ‚Üí Regression ‚Üí Linear

Step 2:  Choose cal_mean as Dependent Variable.
Step 3:  Choose Former and Current under Block 1 of 1 (Independent variables).




The linear regression model is defined as:
\[Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Former_i + \beta_2 Current_i + \epsilon_i\]
where \(\beta_0\) is the intercept term and represents the value corresponding to the reference group or never smokers.

Based on the output, and considering never smokers as the reference group, do individuals who are currently smoking have higher cal_mean measurement than former smokers?: ‚úÖ Interpret the results
















Model
Meaning
Coefficient
p-value
Lower CI
Upper CI
Interpretation




(Constant)
mean CAL for never smokers
0.942
<0.001
0.913
0.971



Former
difference in mean CAL between former smokers and never smokers
0.339
<0.001
0.289
0.388
So former smokers have, on average, 0.34 units higher CAL than never smokers


Current
difference in mean CAL between current smokers and never smokers
0.519
<0.001
0.464
0.573
So current smokers have, on average, 0.52 units higher CAL than never smokers



Summarizing: Compared with never smokers, former smokers have about 0.34 higher mean clinical attachment loss, and current smokers have about 0.52 higher mean clinical attachment loss.





Basically, the results from a linear regression are valid if the assumptions of linear regression are met. These assumptions are:

Linearity between the outcome and the covariates
Independence of the observations
Normality of the residuals
Homoscedasticity: constant variance of the residuals

Note: For more details, check the lecture.






Background



By design:

We ensure that the observations are derived from independent participants.
We ensure that the target variable of our model is normally distributed.





Check whether cal_mean or ln_loss are normally distributed, graphically and statistically.
üí° SPSS:

Analyze ‚Üí Descriptive statistics ‚Üí Explore

Step 2:  Dependent list: cal_mean and ln_loss.
Step 3:  Plots: Check Histogram and Normality plots with tests.







Histogram of the distribution of mean attachment loss





Q-Q plot of the distribution of mean attachment loss










Histogram of the distribution of the natural logarithm of attachment loss





Q-Q plot of the distribution of the natural logarithm of attachment loss






Check graphically the linearity assumption between ln_loss and other continuous variables you want to consider adding to your model (potential confounders).
For that purpose, create a scatter plot:
üí° SPSS:

Graphs ‚Üí Chart Builder

Step 2:  Gallery >> Scatter/Dot >> Drag ‚ÄòScatter plot‚Äô to preview.
Step 3:  Y-axis: ln_loss.
Step 4:  X-axis: alcg (independent).
Add regression line: Double click graph >> Add Fit Line at Total >> Select Linear.
Create another graph for height and weight. Compare the two. Which one shows a linear relationship?







Scatter plot ln_loss vs alcg





Scatter plot ln_loss vs height





Scatter plot ln_loss vs weight






One way to deal with non-linearity is to introduce a quadratic expression. For the relationship between ln_loss and alcg, add a quadratic term.
Then, create quadratic term: Create new variable alcg2 = alcg * alcg.
üí° SPSS:

Transform ‚Üí Compute Variables

Step 2:  Target Variable: alcg2. Numeric Expression: alcg * alcg.



Homoscedasticity means that the independent variable do not affect the residuals.
Check the homoscedasticity assumption graphically and statistically.
Graphically:
üí° SPSS:

Analyze ‚Üí Regression ‚Üí Linear

In the Linear Regression window choose ln_loss as Dependent variable and alcg as Independent(s) variable.





Click Statistics‚Ä¶ and select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model fit, R squared change, Part and partial correlations, Collinearity diagnostics, Casewise diagnostics.





Then, click Plots‚Ä¶ and select Histogram and Normal probability plot. In the Scatter 1 of 1 section add *ZRESID (Standardized residual) as Y: and *ZARED (Standardized predicted value) as X:.





From the output, report the correlation Coefficient, are the two variables correlated?
Statistically (Breusch-Pagan test):
üí° SPSS:

Analyze ‚Üí General Linear Model ‚Üí Univariate

In the Univariate window, select ln_loss as the Dependent Variable and alcg as the Covariate(s) variable.





Click Options‚Ä¶ and select Modified Breusch-Pagan test and Parameter estimates with robust standard error.














Interpretation:

The null hypothesis (H‚ÇÄ): constant variance of residuals (homoscedasticity).
p = 0.373 ‚Üí not significant.

Conclusion:
DO NOT reject the null ‚Üí No evidence of heteroskedasticity. Residual variance appears constant. Homoscedasticity assumption is met.





We hypothesize that the impact of alcohol on attachment loss differs by gender.


Introduce an interaction term between gender (sex) and alcohol consumption (alcg).
1. Create a dummy variable for male using the ‚Äòsex‚Äô variable:

Transform ‚Üí Recode into Different Variables

Assign the value 1 to the variable male and the value 0 to the variable female.


    
    
    

 2. Create interaction variable (AlcMale):
üí° Remember in SPSS:

Transform ‚Üí Compute variable

In the Compute Variable window, in the Target Variable field, type AlcMale.
In the Numeric Expression field, type alcg * male.





3. Fit multivariable model:
üí° SPSS:

Analyze ‚Üí Regression ‚Üí Linear

Step 2:  Dependent: attachment loss
Step 3:  Independent: male, alcg, AlcMale.





Equation: \(Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Male + \beta_2 alcg + \beta_3 alcg*Male + \epsilon_i\)









Interpretation:

Intercept: The expected attachment loss of an adult Female with 0g alcohol.
Male: Males have, on average, a 0.336 increase in attachment loss compared to females.
alcg: Each 1-unit increase in alcohol consumption is associated with a 0.004 increase in attachment loss.
AlcMale: Whether alcohol consumption has an impact on attachment loss depends on gender.






Consider:

Equation: \(Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Male + \beta_2 alcg + \beta_3 alcg*Male\)
the coding for male variable (0 = Female, 1 = Male), and
the continuous variable alcg.

The CAL for a male that consumes 1g of alcohol is:
\(0.851 + 0.336 * 1 + 0.004 * 10 + 0.002 * 10 * 1 = 1.187\)
The CAL for a female that consumes 0g of alcohol is:
\(0.851 + 0.336 * 0 + 0.004 * 0 + 0.002 * 0 * 0 = 0.851\)

title: Praktikum
text: When working with a new dataset, you should first familiarize yourself with its variables and codings. Examples of this are given in Tasks 1 and 2. A graphical representation, as in the following exercises, can provide a substantive overview of the data.

title: Praktikum
text:
Task 1
What is the level of measurement (scale type) for Gender/sex, Body Mass Index (BMI), and BMI categories?
First, answer this question based on your knowledge from the lecture, and then check whether the variables are correctly coded in SPSS.
To do this, switch from the Data View to the Variable View.‚öôÔ∏è














Variable
(SPSS) Scale type
General type
Values




Gender
Nominal
Unordered categorical
Male, Female


BMI
Scale
Continous



BMI categories
Nominal (?)
Ordered categorical
< 18.5, 18.5-25, 25-30 - \(\geq\) 30









Tip




unordered vs ordered categorical?
scale if you can, for example, meaningfully add, subtract, or average




How does the level of measurement (scale level) of the variable number of teeth differ from that of body height or BMI index?

Nature
SPSS Measure

Continuous numeric
Scale
Can take decimal values


Number of teeth
Discrete numeric
Scale
Only integer values, but still numeric

title: Practical 2
text:
In this session, we will cover the first steps in SPSS, including the descriptive analysis of a single variable and the (apparent) relationship between two variables. The following methods will be applied today:

Graphical representations of quantitative variables: bar charts, histograms, boxplots, and Q‚ÄìQ plots
Qualitative variables: cross-tabulations, relative frequencies, risk difference, relative risk, and odds ratio
Quantitative variables: scatterplots, covariance, and correlation coefficient



üì• Download the dataset nhanes30.sav and open it in SPSS ‚Äî either by drag and drop üñ±Ô∏è or via the File menu üóÇÔ∏è ‚Üí Open.

title: Practical 2
text:
Task 3
Create a cross-table for diabetes (diab) and periodontitis (perio2).
üí° In SPSS:

ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí DESKRIPTIVE STATISTIKEN ‚Üí KREUZTABELLEN







Tip



Which variable you assign to the rows or columns is up to you. However, it may be helpful to think of a consistent system ‚Äî for example, ‚ÄúOutcome on top,‚Äù meaning the outcome variable is placed in the columns.






diab √ó perio2 Crosstabulation



diab
perio2 = periodontitis
perio2 = no
Total




diabetes
199

6,290

title: Practical 2
text:
Task 4
Calculate the risk difference, relative risk, and odds ratio for the association between diabetes and periodontitis.
üí° In SPSS:

ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí DESKRIPTIVE STATISTIKEN ‚Üí KREUZTABELLEN

Then in the Crosstabs dialog, click [Cells‚Ä¶] and under Percentages, select Row, then click Continue.
Next, click [Statistics‚Ä¶], check Risk, and click Continue.
Calculate manually:



Risk difference (RD)
Subtract the percentage values: \[
RD = p_{\text{diabetic w/ perio}} - p_{\text{non-diabetic w/ perio}}
\]


Relative risk (RR)
Divide the percentage values: \[
RR = \frac{p_{\text{diabetic w/ perio}}}{p_{\text{non-diabetic w/ perio}}}
\]






Odds ratio (OR) The ratio of odds between the two groups:



The odds of periodontitis for diabetics: \[
    \text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}} =
    \frac{\text{No. diabetic w/ periodontitis}}
         {\text{No. diabetic w/o periodontitis}}
\]



Divided by the odds of periodontitis for non-diabetics: \[
\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}} =
\frac{\text{No. non-diabetic w/ periodontitis}}
         {\text{No. non-diabetic w/o periodontitis}}
\]



Final odds ratio \[
    OR=\frac{\text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}}}{\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}}}
      = \frac{a/b}{c/d}
      = \frac{a \times d}{b \times c}
\]


```
where:
- ( a ): diabetics with periodontitis
- ( b ): diabetics without periodontitis
- ( c ): non-diabetics with periodontitis
- ( d ): non-diabetics without periodontitis

Manual calculations
\[
  RD = 25.6\% - 13.6\%  = 12\%
  \]




 - ‚ö†Ô∏è Remember, this may only be an apparent association - The risk of periodontitis is 12 percentage points higher in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. - This means for every 100 people, about 12 more cases of periodontitis occur among those with diabetes.

\[
  RR = \frac{25.6\%}{13.6\%} = 1.88
  \]




 - Individuals with diabetes have 1.88 times the risk of periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.

\[
  OR = \frac{25.6/74.4}{13.6/86.4} = \frac{25.6 \times 86.4}{74.4 \times 13.6} = \frac{2211.84}{1011.84} = 2.19
  \]




 - People with diabetes have 2.19 times higher odds of having periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.

Which variable you assign to the rows or columns is up to you. However, it may be helpful to think of a consistent system ‚Äî for example, ‚ÄúOutcome on top,‚Äù meaning the outcome variable is placed in the columns.

title: Notes
text:
Task 4
Calculate the risk difference, relative risk, and odds ratio for the association between diabetes and periodontitis.
üí° In SPSS:

ANALYSIEREN ‚Üí DESKRIPTIVE STATISTIKEN ‚Üí KREUZTABELLEN

Then in the Crosstabs dialog, click [Cells‚Ä¶] and under Percentages, select Row, then click Continue.
Next, click [Statistics‚Ä¶], check Risk, and click Continue.
Calculate manually:



Risk difference (RD)
Subtract the percentage values: \[
RD = p_{\text{diabetic w/ perio}} - p_{\text{non-diabetic w/ perio}}
\]


Relative risk (RR)
Divide the percentage values: \[
RR = \frac{p_{\text{diabetic w/ perio}}}{p_{\text{non-diabetic w/ perio}}}
\]






Odds ratio (OR) The ratio of odds between the two groups:



The odds of periodontitis for diabetics: \[
    \text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}} =
    \frac{\text{No. diabetic w/ periodontitis}}
         {\text{No. diabetic w/o periodontitis}}
\]



Divided by the odds of periodontitis for non-diabetics: \[
\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}} =
\frac{\text{No. non-diabetic w/ periodontitis}}
         {\text{No. non-diabetic w/o periodontitis}}
\]



Final odds ratio \[
    OR=\frac{\text{Odds}_{\text{diabetic}}}{\text{Odds}_{\text{non-diabetic}}}
      = \frac{a/b}{c/d}
      = \frac{a \times d}{b \times c}
\]


```
where:
- ( a ): diabetics with periodontitis
- ( b ): diabetics without periodontitis
- ( c ): non-diabetics with periodontitis
- ( d ): non-diabetics without periodontitis

Let the 2√ó2 table be:




Periodontitis (+)

Diabetic
( a )
( b )

 - ‚ö†Ô∏è Remember, this may only be an apparent association - The risk of periodontitis is 12 percentage points higher in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. - This means for every 100 people, about 12 more cases of periodontitis occur among those with diabetes.

\[
  RR = \frac{25.6\%}{13.6\%} = 1.88

 - Individuals with diabetes have 1.88 times the risk of periodontitis compared with those without diabetes.

title: Welcome to the Practical Course
text:
Welcome to the Practical Course
Explore, analyze, and learn with NHANES data.



üìä Data Analysis
We will use data from the NHANES (1999‚Äì2003) to describe the health status of the U.S. population (ages 30-85).


üìÅ The Dataset
The data is stored in nhanes30.sav. This file contains observed data, variable descriptions, and metadata.









.sav?



.sav extension indicates an SPSS file, which contains the observed data, variable descriptions, and metadata.
